thread.title: Surf champs crowned at First Peak
thread.title_full: Surf champs crowned at First Peak

title: Surf champs crowned at First Peak
text:
Surf champs crowned at First Peak Sue DeWerff For FLORIDA TODAY 9:12 p.m. EDT October 11, 2015 William Hedleston 30 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
It was a battle between groms, juniors, seniors and even a few of Brevard’s East Coast Legends during this weekend’s annual ASF (Atlantic Surfing Federation’s) Championships — as surfers in 22 divisions from as far as New Jersey and South Carolina competed at the famed Sebastian Inlet’s First Peak. 
The contest, in its fourth year — one that allows competitors to gain valuable points toward qualifying for the 2016 Surfing America Prime events in California next summer — not only saw excellent surfing, but an exhibition reuniting several of Brevard’s East Coast Hall of Famers and former pros. 
“We decided to add this division to allow both spectators and competitors alike an opportunity to witness the surfing talents from a few guys who have paved the way here on the East Coast in the surfing world,” said Phil Jackson, executive director. 
Competitors in this division included several of Brevard’s well-known names: Matt Kechele, David Speir, Todd Holland, Bryan Hewiston, Paul Reniecke and Barry Pasonski; along with South Carolina’s Bob Weaver, all whom put on an amazing show. 
In the end, it was Speir who reigned victorious. 
“This was so much fun, a great day to be able to get out there with these guys whom I have surfed with for the past 20 years or more at this break,” Speir said. 
His combined two-wave total of nearly 15 was one he said he was proud to accomplish, given the smaller wave conditions. 
Reinkcke was second, followed by Holland and Pasonski. 
“I felt like a grom again out there. We are all friends and began surfing here at the inlet together back in the ’80s,” Pasonski said. 
In the Men’s Open division, Melbourne High School team member Chauncey Robinson prevailed, bringing home one of nine division titles for Brevard. He was also the back-to-back winner of the U-18 division. 
“I’m stoked,” Robinson said. “I am looking forward to leading the Bulldogs to victory at the NSSA (National Scholastic Surfing Association’s) high school event this year. The waves, though much smaller than the last few weeks, of course, were really fun.” 
In the U-12 division, Cocoa Beach 11-year-old William Hedleston earned the right to be chaired to the beach and a first-place trophy that stood almost his height. His smile was enough to show his satisfaction for his efforts. 
“I’ve gone back and forth with these guys in a lot of different events, they are all good surfers. I am thankful for this win here,” he smiled. He also took third in the U-14 division. 
On the female side, 10-year-old Zoe Benedetto, who noted she has won every local ASF chapter event throughout this season in the U-12 division, showed why she deserved to win this championship event as well. Her rides to the beach, maneuvering the waves with clever cutbacks, had all judges putting her in first throughout the heat. 
“You just have to believe in yourself,” she said. “I plan on competing in NSSA as well this season. I love to surf.” 
Rachel Presti, 13, a familiar Space Coast face and name, as well, was the winner of both the U-14 and U-16 divisions and took third in the U-18. She will be headed next week to California again to support the ISA (International Surfing America) team, one in which she will be an alternate competitor. She will also be looking forward to surfing the annual Ron Jon Beach and Boards Festival WSL Junior Women’s pro next spring again. 
Rounding out the top winners for Brevard were Lauren McClean Holland, who was first in the Ladies division and Randy Nolan, who took first in the Senior Men’s division. 
Nolan, who ministers to youth at several Brevard locations, said he was thrilled to have won his first ASF Championship title. 
“I used to compete years ago, and decided to get back into it just recently, so I am really stoked. The folks who run this event here are great and the vibe is awesome,” Nolan said. 
ASF Championships results
